awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Modern Oil-based Paints:  A Mechanistic Approach to Assessing and Modeling their Curing, Aging and Cleaning
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

Investigations of paint coatings in the context of cultural heritage science present a unique set of technical challenges because of the evolution of the properties of materials over time scales that are much too long to be reproduced directly.  As a result, data-driven kinetic models of the aging process are needed in order to understand the physical state of aged paints and to develop effective restoration and cleaning strategies.  In this collaborative project involving Northwestern University and the Art Institute of Chicago, a kinetic Monte Carlo model of paint curing and aging will be developed, as will experimental systems needed to determine relevant model parameters.  The net result will be a set of simulation models that can be viewed as 'virtual' oil-based paint coatings.  These 'virtual' coatings will enable the time dependent, structural features of complex, multicomponent paint coatings to be tracked.  The models, with their experimentally determined input parameters, represent a physical and chemical knowledge base for oil-based paint coatings that will serve as a platform for addressing a wide range of questions. Specific issues to be addressed concern the curing and aging of systems when subjected to heat, humidity and various cleaning solutions.  Kinetic parameters will be determined experimentally with coatings made from well characterized starting materials, using the quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) as the primary experimental tool.  Nanoindentation will be used to correlate the high frequency mechanical response obtained with the QCM to complementary measures of the mechanical response and to actual paint samples.  While these techniques will be applied directly to oil-based coatings used by artists, the methodology is broadly applicable in a variety of areas, including characterization of high performance protective coatings, and the development of sustainable, bio-derived materials.  

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

This project is a collaborative effort between Northwestern University and the Art Institute of Chicago.  State-of-the art scientific tools will be used to study the curing and aging properties of modern oil-based paints and the impact of conservation treatments on them. Although oil-based paints were widely used throughout the 20th century, and in some of the most prominent artworks of that period, their properties are poorly understood. Advancing our knowledge in this area is crucial for preserving the integrity of such artworks for future generations. The results of this research will be used to develop more effective conservation strategies for paintings in collections at the Art Institute and at other museums throughout the world.  An educational outreach element linking science and art will also be developed in conjunction with the Art Institute's Department of Museum Education.  Outreach offerings will be developed to attract middle school and high school science classes to the museum.  These activities will be designed to attract students to science who would otherwise not likely be drawn to science-related programs.  Similarly, the connection with the Art Institute will enable undergraduate and graduate students at Northwestern to understand the ways in which scientific concepts can benefit disciplines that lie outside the traditional scientific realm.

This project represents an innovative application of advanced scientific research to deepen our understanding of the mechanisms involved in the aging and degradation of materials used to create historic objects and works of art. Painted works of art have played an important role in capturing cultural attitudes and events. Like many other creative endeavors of humanity across history, they contribute to our understanding of our place in the world. From a material standpoint, paintings are extremely complex objects, containing many heterogeneous layers of pigment, binder and other additives applied to common substrates such as canvas or wood. Over time, paintings experience a variety of chemical and mechanical stresses, both internal, such as chemical or light-induced degradation, and external, such as temperature and humidity cycling, moving and cleaning. A significant fraction of paintings and other painted artworks have been created with drying oils as the paint binder. Consequently, it is important to understand the complex mechanisms governing the long term chemical and mechanical stability of these oil-based paints to ensure their preservation for future generations.
The role that this project has played in this field is illustrated in Figure 1. In general, an artist begins with a set of starting materials and production methods (which are not always known in detail) and produces an object that continues to evolve and age over time. Through a variety of investigations including scientific analysis and close observation, the conservation science community develops an understanding of the aged paint in as much detail as possible. We refer to this understanding as a ’Virtual Paint’, in that it is an incomplete picture of the actual paint, generated from the information that is available. In this project both experimental and computational methods have been developed that are used to bring the Virtual Paint into closer conformity with reality, opening the path to predicting the properties of such paints over time.
Several methods have been utilized in the experimental component of this project. The primary tool is based on careful measurements of the vibrations of quartz crystals onto which fresh paint layers have been applied. The technique utilizes the principles responsible for the precision of modern quartz watches and time-keeping devices. The technique generates accurate property information as the paint hardens and ages in real time, including determining what are the changes to be expected after exposure to heat or humidity, but cannot be utilized directly with historic paint samples. For this reason complementary experimental techniques that can be used on very small samples have also been developed. These complementary techniques can be used on actual historic paint samples without visibly damaging the artwork, to measure, for example, how brittle they have become with time and give improved recommendations on their storage or handling.
If we can create a simulation, or model, generated by a computer that has the same exact properties of the paints that we are studying, then this is also a very powerful tool for their preservation and care. A key outcome of the project has been the development of a computational framework that enables the enormous number of chemical components present in an actual paint sample to be accurately tracked. With inputs from experimental data obtained from the experiments (as illustrated in Figure 1), an accurate Virtual Paint can be developed.
